query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Io non m’accorsi del salire in ella; 14 ma d’esservi entro mi fé assai fede 15 la donna mia ch’i’ vidi far più bella.
query.result:
**English:**
13 I did not notice the ascent into it; 14 but that I was within it gave me sure proof 15 my lady whom I saw become more beautiful.
**Old English:**
13 Ic ne ongeat ðæs upstiges on ða, 14 ac ðæt ic ðærbinnan wæs me fela gelyfde 15 min lafdige ðe ic ðær geseah fægerre weorðan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 E come in fiamma favilla si vede, 17 e come in voce voce si discerne, 18 quand’ una è ferma e altra va e riede,
19 vid’ io in essa luce altre lucerne 20 muoversi in giro più e men correnti, 21 al modo, credo, di lor viste interne.
query.result:
**English:**
16 And as a spark is seen in flame, 17 and as a voice is discerned in voice, 18 when one is steady and the other goes and returns,
19 I saw in that light other lights 20 moving in a circle, faster and slower, 21 in the manner, I believe, of their inner vision.
**Old English:**
16 And swa swa on lige liget bið gesewen, 17 and swa swa on stefne stefn bið oncnawen, 18 ðonne an is fæst and oðer gæð and cymð,
19 ða geseah ic on ðam leohte oðre leoht 20 on ymbhwyrftum farende swiðor and læs, 21 æfter ðam ðe me ðuhte heora inwit gleaw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Di fredda nube non disceser venti, 23 o visibili o no, tanto festini, 24 che non paressero impediti e lenti
25 a chi avesse quei lumi divini 26 veduti a noi venir, lasciando il giro 27 pria cominciato in li alti Serafini;
28 e dentro a quei che più innanzi appariro 29 sonava ‘Osanna’ sì, che unque poi 30 di rïudir non fui sanza disiro.
query.result:
**English:**
22 From the cold cloud no winds descended, 23 visible or not, so swift, 24 that they did not seem impeded and slow
25 to one who had seen those divine lights 26 come toward us, leaving the circle 27 begun earlier among the high Seraphim;
28 and within those who appeared in front 29 resounded “Hosanna” so that never after 30 was I without the desire to hear it again.
**Old English:**
22 Of cealdum wolcne ne comon windas, 23 gesewene oððe ungemet, swa fæste, 24 ðæt ne þuhton aþrotene and late
25 ðam ðe hæfde ða leohte lihte 26 gesegen to us cuman, forlætende ðone hring 27 ær ongunnen on ðam hean Seraphinum;
28 and innan ðam ðe ðær formast æteowdon 29 song ‘Osanna’ swa ðæt næfre siððan 30 ne wæs ic ðæs willan butan wædle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Indi si fece l’un più presso a noi 32 e solo incominciò: «Tutti sem presti 33 al tuo piacer, perché di noi ti gioi.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then one of them drew nearer to us 32 and began to speak alone: "We are all ready 33 to do your bidding, because you delight in us.
**Old English:**
31 Þa wearð heora sum snelra getenge 32 and ðus anhaga ædre ongeat: 33 "We syndon ðine geongran gearo,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Noi ci volgiam coi principi celesti 35 d’un giro e d’un girare e d’una sete, 36 ai quali tu del mondo già dicesti:
37 ‘Voi che ’ntendendo il terzo ciel movete’; 38 e sem sì pien d’amor, che, per piacerti, 39 non fia men dolce un poco di quïete».
query.result:
**English:**
34 We revolve with the celestial princes 35 in a gyre and a gyration and a thirst, 36 to whom you once said of the world:
37 ‘You who, in understanding, move the third heaven’; 38 and I seem so full of love that, to please you, 39 a little quiet will be no less sweet.”
**Old English:**
34 We us wendon mid ðæm heofonlicum ealdrum 35 on anre hweorfunze and anre ymbhwyrftum and anre ðurste, 36 ðæm ðu iu cwæde be ðære worulde:
37 ‘Ge ðe ðurh andzit ðone ðriddan heofon styriað’; 38 and ic ðuhte swa full of lufe, ðæt ðe to gecwemanne, 39 ne bið no ðæs wyrs ðin an lytel reste.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Poscia che li occhi miei si fuoro offerti 41 a la mia donna reverenti, ed essa 42 fatti li avea di sé contenti e certi,
43 rivolsersi a la luce che promessa 44 tanto s’avea, e «Deh, chi siete?» fue 45 la voce mia di grande affetto impressa.
query.result:
**English:**
40 After my eyes had offered themselves 41 to my lady, reverently, and she 42 had made them content and certain of herself,
43 they turned to the light that had been promised 44 so much, and "Oh, who are you?" was 45 my voice, marked with great affection.
**Old English:**
40 Siððan ða mine eagan wæron offerede 41 minre ðeofan arwurðlice, and heo 42 hæfde ða geworhte ða geblissfulle and ða geleafan,
43 ða gewendon ða to ðam leohte ðe gehaten 44 wæs swa micel, and "Eala, hwa synd ge?" wæs 45 min stefn mid micelre lufe awriten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 E quanta e quale vid’ io lei far piùe 47 per allegrezza nova che s’accrebbe, 48 quando parlai, a l’allegrezze sue!
49 Così fatta, mi disse: «Il mondo m’ebbe 50 giù poco tempo; e se più fosse stato, 51 molto sarà di mal, che non sarebbe.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And how much and how beautiful I saw her become 47 through the new joy that increased, 48 when I spoke, to her joys!
49 Thus made, she said to me: "The world had me 50 down below for a short time; and if it had been longer, 51 there would be much evil that would not be.
**Old English:**
46 And hu micel and hu fæger ic ða geseah 47 ðurh ða niwan blisse ðe ðær gewearð, 48 ða ic ðurh hire spræce to ðam gefean com!
49 ðus geworden, heo cwæð to me: "Me hæfde 50 ðeos world on hyre anwealde lytle hwile; and gif hit leng wære, 51 ðonne wære fela yfeles ðe nu nis.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 La mia letizia mi ti tien celato 53 che mi raggia dintorno e mi nasconde 54 quasi animal di sua seta fasciato.
query.result:
**English:**
52 My joy keeps you hidden from me, 53 which radiates around me and conceals you, 54 like an animal wrapped in its silk.
**Old English:**
52 Min gefean ðe ðe digelne gehealdeð, 53 ðe ðe scineð embe me and ðe me hyleð, 54 swylce deor gediglod ðære sidan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Assai m’amasti, e avesti ben onde; 56 che s’io fossi giù stato, io ti mostrava 57 di mio amor più oltre che le fronde.
query.result:
**English:**
55 You loved me greatly, and you had good reason; 56 for if I had been down below, I would have shown you 57 more of my love than just the leaves.
**Old English:**
55 Swiðe ðu ðe me lufode, and ðu hæfdest wel hwi; 56 forðæm gif ic niðer wære, ðonne wolde ic ðe gecyðan 57 minre lufe mare ðonne ða leaf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Quella sinistra riva che si lava 59 di Rodano poi ch’è misto con Sorga, 60 per suo segnore a tempo m’aspettava,
61 e quel corno d’Ausonia che s’imborga 62 di Bari e di Gaeta e di Catona, 63 da ove Tronto e Verde in mare sgorga.
query.result:
**English:**
58 That sinister shore that is washed 59 by the Rhone after it has mingled with the Sorgue, 60 awaited me in due time as my lord,
61 and that horn of Ausonia which is adorned 62 with Bari, Gaeta, and Catona, 63 from where the Tronto and the Verde flow into the sea.
**Old English:**
58 Se wælstrem ðe wæsceð 59 ðurh Rodan siððan he bið gemenged mid Sorgea, 60 for his hlaforde on ðam gefealledan timan mec onbad,
61 and se ende Ausonia ðe bið getimbred 62 mid Barium and mid Gaieta and mid Catona, 63 of ðam ðe Tronto and Verde on sæ floweð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Fulgeami già in fronte la corona 65 di quella terra che ’l Danubio riga 66 poi che le ripe tedesche abbandona.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Now the crown of that land was shining on my brow, 65 which the Danube waters after it leaves 66 the German banks.
**Old English:**
64 Me ða ðære ceastre cyning 65 on ðam lande ðe ðone Danubie 66 ofer ða Tyscan ea flówende wæg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 E la bella Trinacria, che caliga 68 tra Pachino e Peloro, sopra ’l golfo 69 che riceve da Euro maggior briga,
70 non per Tifeo ma per nascente solfo, 71 attesi avrebbe li suoi regi ancora, 72 nati per me di Carlo e di Ridolfo,
73 se mala segnoria, che sempre accora 74 li popoli suggetti, non avesse 75 mosso Palermo a gridar: “Mora, mora!”.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And fair Trinacria, which lies 68 between Pachino and Peloro, above the gulf 69 that receives the greatest force from the east wind,
70 not because of Typhon but because of the sulfur that is born there, 71 would still be awaiting its kings, 72 born for me from Charles and Rudolph,
73 if bad governance, which always grieves 74 the subject peoples, had not 75 stirred up Palermo to cry out: “Death, death!”.
**Old English:**
67 And ðæt fægere Trinacria, ðe lið 68 betwux Pachino and Peloro, ofer ðæm sægulf 69 ðe onfehð ðone mæstan brygan of ðæm eastan wind,
70 nis ðurh Tifeo ac ðurh ðone swefl ðe ðær spryngð, 71 ða gyt wunigean his cyningas, 72 acænned for me of Carle and of Rodulf,
73 gif ðæt yfele weald, ðe symle ðreageð 74 ða folc ðe him underðeodde sind, næfde 75 awæcced Palerme ðæt hit cleopode: “Deað, deað!”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 La sua natura, che di larga parca 83 discese, avria mestier di tal milizia 84 che non curasse di mettere in arca».
query.result:
**English:**
82 His nature, which descended from a generous stock, 83 would have need of such a retinue 84 that would not care to put money in the strongbox.
**Old English:**
82 His gecynd, ðe of ðære micclan mægðe 83 asteah, hæfde ðæs mægnes behof, 84 ðe ne rohte on hord to legganne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 «Però ch’i’ credo che l’alta letizia 86 che ’l tuo parlar m’infonde, segnor mio, 87 là ’ve ogne ben si termina e s’inizia,
88 per te si veggia come la vegg’ io, 89 grata m’è più; e anco quest’ ho caro 90 perché ’l discerni rimirando in Dio.
query.result:
**English:**
85 “But because I believe that the great joy 86 that your words instill in me, my lord, 87 there where every good thing ends and begins,
88 may be seen by me as you see it, 89 it is more pleasing to me; and this too I hold dear 90 because you discern it by looking into God.
**Old English:**
85 Ac ðeah ðe ic gelyfe ðæt ðæt heæhste blis 86 ðe ðin word on me aweceð, min hlaford, 87 ðær ælc gōd ðing geendod bið and onginneð,
88 ðurh ðe gesewen swa swa ðu hit gesihst, 89 me bið ðe leofre; and ðis ic ðeah ðæs geornor 90 forðæm ðe ðu hit on Gode gesihst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Fatto m’hai lieto, e così mi fa chiaro, 92 poi che, parlando, a dubitar m’hai mosso 93 com’ esser può, di dolce seme, amaro».
query.result:
**English:**
91 You have made me glad, and thus you make it clear to me, 92 since, by speaking, you have moved me to doubt 93 how it can be that from sweet seed comes bitterness.
**Old English:**
91 Þu me hæfst gemacod bliðe, and swa ðu me geopenast, 92 siððan ðu sprecende, ðu me hæfst astyred to tweonum, 93 hu hit mæg beon, of swete sæde, biter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Questo io a lui; ed elli a me: «S’io posso 95 mostrarti un vero, a quel che tu dimandi 96 terrai lo viso come tien lo dosso.
query.result:
**English:**
94 This I said to him; and he to me: "If I can 95 show you a true way, to that which you ask, 96 you will keep your face as you keep your back."
**Old English:**
94 Þis ic him sæde; and he to me: "Gif ic mæg 95 æteowian ðe soðne weg, to ðæm ðe ðu axast, 96 ðu hæfst ðinne neb swa ðu hæfst ðinne hrycg."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Lo ben che tutto il regno che tu scandi 98 volge e contenta, fa esser virtute 99 sua provedenza in questi corpi grandi.
query.result:
**English:**
97 The good which all the realm that you ascend 98 turns and contents, makes virtue to be 99 its providence in these great bodies.
**Old English:**
97 Þæt god ðe eall ðæt rice ðe ðu ræst 98 gewent and wended, wyrðeð to fremme 99 his foreþonca on ðam miclan lichoman.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 E non pur le nature provedute 101 sono in la mente ch’è da sé perfetta, 102 ma esse insieme con la lor salute:
103 per che quantunque quest’ arco saetta 104 disposto cade a proveduto fine, 105 sì come cosa in suo segno diretta.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And not only the natures provided for 101 are in the mind that is perfect in itself, 102 but they together with their salvation:
103 so that however much this bow shoots 104 it falls disposed to a provided end, 105 just like a thing directed at its mark.
**Old English:**
100 And na ða ðing ðe ðurh ða gecynde beoð 101 on ðam mode ðe is ðurh hine sylfne fulfremed, 102 ac ða ðing ða ðurh ða gecynde beoð mid heora hæle:
103 for ði ðe ðeah ðe ðeos stræl ðurh ðone bogan fleoge 104 ðonne bið he ðurh ða gecynde ðurh ðone bogan gewyld to ðam ende ðe him geteohhod wæs, 105 swa swa ðing ðe bið to his mæðe gerihted.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Vuo’ tu che questo ver più ti s’imbianchi?». 113 E io: «Non già; ché impossibil veggio 114 che la natura, in quel ch’è uopo, stanchi».
query.result:
**English:**
112 Do you want this truth to become clearer to you? 113 And I: "Not at all; for I see it is impossible 114 that nature, in what is necessary, should ever grow weary."
**Old English:**
112 Wylt ðu ðæt ðeos soð þe swutolor sy? 113 And ic: "Nis na; forðæm ic geseo ðæt hit unmihtelic is 114 ðæt seo gecynd on ðam ðe hire nied is æfre gewemme."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Ond’ elli ancora: «Or dì: sarebbe il peggio 116 per l’omo in terra, se non fosse cive?». 117 «Sì», rispuos’ io; «e qui ragion non cheggio».
query.result:
**English:**
115 And he to me again: "Now tell me, would it be the worst 116 for a man on earth, if he were not a citizen?" 117 "Yes," I replied; "and here I ask no reasons."
**Old English:**
115 Ond he eft ða cwæð: "Saga me nu ðonne, gif hit swa wære, 116 ðæt nære mon on eorðan, gif he nære burhsittende?" 117 "Gese," cwæð ic, "ond ðæs ic ðe ræd ne bidde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 «E puot’ elli esser, se giù non si vive 119 diversamente per diversi offici? 120 Non, se ’l maestro vostro ben vi scrive».
query.result:
**English:**
118 And can there be good government, if down below 119 people do not live differently according to different offices? 120 No, if your master writes to you correctly.
**Old English:**
118 And mæg ðær ænig wealdan wel, gif he nyðera 119 mislice ne leofað be mislicum ðeawum? 120 Nis, gif eow ænig ealdor wel læreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Sì venne deducendo infino a quici; 122 poscia conchiuse: «Dunque esser diverse 123 convien di vostri effetti le radici:
124 per ch’un nasce Solone e altro Serse, 125 altro Melchisedèch e altro quello 126 che, volando per l’aere, il figlio perse.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Thus she brought her argument down to this point; 122 then she concluded: "Therefore the roots 123 of your effects must be diverse:
124 for which reason one is born Solon, another Xerxes, 125 another Melchizedek, and another he 126 who, flying through the air, lost his son.
**Old English:**
121 Swa heo ða rædde oð ðone ende; 122 ða heo ðus cwæð: "Nu is ðearf ðætte 123 ðinra weorca wyrtruman synd
124 mislice: forðæm bið geboren sum 125 Salomon and sum Serxes, 126 sum Melchisedech and sum se
127 ðe fleogende ðurh lyft his sunu forleas."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 La circular natura, ch’è suggello 128 a la cera mortal, fa ben sua arte, 129 ma non distingue l’un da l’altro ostello.
query.result:
**English:**
127 The circular nature, which is the seal 128 to the mortal wax, does its art well, 129 but it does not distinguish one dwelling from another.
**Old English:**
127 Se hringende gecynd, ðe is insegl 128 ðære deadlican wæxe, wyrcð wel his cræft, 129 ac he ne todæleð ðone ænne eardungstede fram ðam oðrum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Quinci addivien ch’Esaù si diparte 131 per seme da Iacòb; e vien Quirino 132 da sì vil padre, che si rende a Marte.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Hence it comes that Esau departs 131 by seed from Jacob; and Quirinus comes 132 from so vile a father that he surrenders to Mars.
**Old English:**
130 Heonon cymð ðæt Esaú síððan 131 ðurh sæd fram Iacobe; and Quirinus cymeð 132 fram swá lytlum fæder ðæt he síððan underpeoded Martem.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Natura generata il suo cammino 134 simil farebbe sempre a’ generanti, 135 se non vincesse il proveder divino.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Nature, generated, would always make 134 her course like to the generators, 135 if divine foresight did not overcome.
**Old English:**
133 Nis ðæt ðære niwe ðæs ðe ðu spricst, 134 ðæt ðeos gesceaft sceal gelice faren 135 ðæm ðe ða gesceafta gesceop, 136 gif ðæs ne wile waldend god.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Or quel che t’era dietro t’è davanti: 137 ma perché sappi che di te mi giova, 138 un corollario voglio che t’ammanti.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Now what was behind you is before you: 137 but so that you know that I take pleasure in you, 138 I want a corollary to adorn you.
**Old English:**
136 Nu ðæt ðe ær wæs æfter ðe bið beforan: 137 ac forðæm ðe ic wille ðæt ðu wite ðæt me licað ðin, 138 ic wille ðæt an oferhyrnes ðe bewrigen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Sempre natura, se fortuna trova 140 discorde a sé, com’ ogne altra semente 141 fuor di sua regïon, fa mala prova.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Nature always makes a poor attempt 140 when fortune finds it 141 discordant with itself, like any other seed 142 outside its own region.
**Old English:**
139 Natura simle ðonne fortune fint 140 unðeorne hire, swa ælc sæd bið, 141 butan his agenre eðle, unweorð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 E se ’l mondo là giù ponesse mente 143 al fondamento che natura pone, 144 seguendo lui, avria buona la gente.
query.result:
**English:**
142 And if the world down there would pay attention 143 to the foundation that nature lays, 144 following it, the people would be good.
**Old English:**
142 And gif ðeos world ðær niðan gemunde 143 ðæs grundwealles ðe gecynd sette, 144 folgiende him, ða folc wæron gode.
